comments.author: WinkyNurdo
comments.body:
From what Iâ€™m aware, the works done were:

Refitting new escalators 

Gutting and refitting the ticket hall with more card reading access points

Removing the ticket office (which was closed anyway)

Refitting and retiling the platforms

Plus unexpected structural problems discovered whilst removing the old knackered escalators 


I used to go past it every morning on the tube from Tufnell Park. One week the platforms had all been graffitied which obviously needed removing. It feels like a lot of work to me, especially knowing the work that goes in to removing and replacing the escalators in confined spaces. But what do I know. The longer it was closed, the more revenue they lost, presumably.

comments.author: Recessio_
comments.body:
Mornington Crescent was closed for six years! 1992 to 1998. Partly because it was in so much worse condition than Kentish Town - needed entirely new lifts, with an old lift being converted into a staircase, a new booking hall with ticket gates, complete rewiring with new fire system, CCTV, emergency call points, restoring heritage tiling, fixing all the leaks etc. 

But also frankly London Transport (as it was back then) didn't have any money, and with Camden, Euston and Warren Street nearby, it wasn't a huge catchment area that was affected so they could get away with it for longer.

comments.author: Lit-Up
comments.body:
It's a 20 minute walk from Camden to Euston station. Crazy to think that there wasn't enough money floating about to refurbish a station on the Zone 1/2 border. The reason it was shut for 6 years is just a money issue. I doubt it would have taken 6 years to fix if the money was there when it broke.

But yeah, it just seems to conjure up a time when there was less money floating around in London I guess, before the property boom, before every pub was converted to flats, when you still had dereliction in parts of central London and a tube station like this could literally sit disused for SIX years!
